# Âü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
export LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
export EDITOR=vim
export SAVEHIST=100000

# To Enable Ctrl+a, Ctrl+e
bindkey -e

# zplug„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
source ~/.zplug/init.zsh

# ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-completions"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-history-substring-search"
zplug "Jxck/dotfiles", as:command, use:"bin/{histuniq,color}"
zplug "tcnksm/docker-alias", use:zshrc
zplug "k4rthik/git-cal", as:command, frozen:1
zplug "lib/clipboard", from:oh-my-zsh, if:"[[ $OSTYPE == *darwin* ]]"
zplug "jhawthorn/fzy", as:command, rename-to:fzy, hook-build:"make && sudo make install"
zplug "b4b4r07/enhancd", at:v1
zplug "mollifier/anyframe", at:4c23cb60
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-syntax-highlighting", defer:2
zplug "~/.zsh", from:local

# „Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥„ÅÆ„Ç§„É≥„Çπ„Éà„Éº„É´
if ! zplug check --verbose; then
  printf "Install? [y/N]: "
  if read -q; then
    echo
    zplug install
  fi
fi

zplug load

# „Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„ÉâË®≠ÂÆö
bindkey '\eOA' history-substring-search-up
bindkey '\eOB' history-substring-search-down
bindkey '^p' history-beginning-search-backward-end
bindkey '^n' history-beginning-search-forward-end
bindkey '^[[A' up-line-or-search
bindkey '^[[B' down-line-or-search

# Â±•Ê≠¥Ê§úÁ¥¢„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
autoload history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-backward-end history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-forward-end history-search-end

# Rust
if [ -d $HOME/.cargo ]; then
  source $HOME/.cargo/env
fi

# Aliases
if [ -f $HOME/.aliases ]; then
  . $HOME/.aliases
fi

# Python (pyenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.pyenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.pyenv/shims:$PATH"
fi

export PATH=${0:A:h}/bin:$PATH

# direnv
eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"

# SSHË£úÂÆå
function _ssh {
  compadd $(fgrep 'Host ' ~/.ssh/*.config | awk '{print $2}' | sort)
}

# poetry
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"


# Node.js (nodenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.nodenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.nodenv/bin:$PATH"
  eval "$(nodenv init -)"
fi

# atuin („Ç∑„Çß„É´Â±•Ê≠¥ÁÆ°ÁêÜ)
if [ -f $HOME/.cargo/bin/atuin ]; then
  eval "$(atuin init zsh)"
fi

# „Éë„ÇπË®≠ÂÆö
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/libpq/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/mysql-client/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/openjdk@17/bin:$PATH"

# jenv
export PATH="$HOME/.jenv/bin:$PATH"
eval "$(jenv init -)"


# SDKMAN
export SDKMAN_DIR="$HOME/.sdkman"
[[ -s "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh" ]] && source "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh"

# asdf
. /opt/homebrew/opt/asdf/libexec/asdf.sh

export DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH="$HOME/.local/lib:$DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH"

# opencode
export PATH="$HOME/.opencode/bin:$PATH"

# bun completions
[ -s "$HOME/.bun/_bun" ] && source "$HOME/.bun/_bun"

# bun
export BUN_INSTALL="$HOME/.bun"
export PATH="$BUN_INSTALL/bin:$PATH"

# Google Cloud SDK
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/path.zsh.inc"
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/completion.zsh.inc"

# claude-mem (memory service for Claude Code)
alias claude-mem="$BUN_INSTALL/bin/bun $HOME/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/thedotmack/plugin/scripts/worker-service.cjs"

/Users/letusfly85/.zsh/git-prompt.zsh/README.md:78:Unlike other popular prompts this prompt does not use `promptinit`, which gives you the flexibility to build your own prompt from scratch.
/Users/letusfly85/.zsh/git-prompt.zsh/README.md:79:You can build a custom prompt by setting the `PROMPT` variable in your `.zshrc` after souring the `git-prompt.zsh`.
/Users/letusfly85/.zsh/git-prompt.zsh/README.md:80:And you should use `'$(gitprompt)'` in your `PROMPT` to get the Git prompt.
/Users/letusfly85/.zsh/git-prompt.zsh/README.md:81:You must set your `PROMPT` with **single quotes**, not double quotes, otherwise the Git prompt will not update properly.
/Users/letusfly85/.zsh/git-prompt.zsh/README.md:82:Some example `PROMPT` configurations are given below.
/Users/letusfly85/.zsh/git-prompt.zsh/README.md:83:You can find more information on how to configure the `PROMPT` in [Zsh's online documentation](http://zsh.sourceforge.net/Doc/Release/Prompt-Expansion.html) or the `zshmisc` manpage, section "SIMPLE PROMPT ESCAPES".

Now I understand the issue. The `git-prompt.zsh` plugin is loaded via `zplug "~/.zsh", from:local` in `.zshrc`. This plugin sets its own PROMPT at line 64-66:

```zsh
[[ "$PROMPT" != *gitprompt* && "$RPROMPT" != *gitprompt* ]] \
    && PROMPT='%B%40<..<%~ %b$(gitprompt)' \
    && PROMPT+='%(?.%(!.%F{white}‚ùØ%F{yellow}‚ùØ%F{red}.%F{blue}‚ùØ%F{cyan}‚ùØ%F{green})‚ùØ.%F{red}‚ùØ‚ùØ‚ùØ)%f '


```

This is generating the `..s [feat/add-minimal-zsh-prompt|‚úî] ‚ùØ‚ùØ‚ùØ` prompt the user is seeing. The directory path gets truncated to 40 characters, and the AWS region or email they mentioned earlier was likely from a cached Starship prompt that's no longer active.

The real issue is that git-prompt.zsh is overriding the PROMPT variable I set in .zshrc. The user wants just the directory, git branch if applicable, and nothing else. I'm realizing the plugin only overrides PROMPT if it doesn't already contain "gitprompt", and since my PROMPT is set before `zplug load`, the plugin should be checking for that string and deciding whether to override it.

```
zshrc
```

The simplest fix is to just remove the `zplug "~/.zsh", from:local` line that's loading git-prompt.zsh in the first place, since my vcs_info setup already handles showing the git branch the way the user wants it.

Let me double-check what else might be in that `~/.zsh` directory though. Looking at the earlier directory listing, it only contains git-prompt.zsh, so removing that zplug line won't break anything else.

Now I need to restructure the .zshrc file: remove the zplug load for that local directory, and move the PROMPT configuration to after zplug finishes loading everything, so no plugins can override my simple prompt setup.

# Âü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
export LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
export EDITOR=vim
export SAVEHIST=100000

# „Éó„É≠„É≥„Éó„ÉàË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Ç´„É¨„É≥„Éà„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ + git„Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç„ÅÆ„ÅøÔºâ
autoload -Uz vcs_info
precmd() { vcs_info }
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' formats ' (%b)'
setopt PROMPT_SUBST
PROMPT='%~${vcs_info_msg_0_} $ '

# To Enable Ctrl+a, Ctrl+e
bindkey -e

# zplug„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
source ~/.zplug/init.zsh

# ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-completions"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-history-substring-search"
zplug "Jxck/dotfiles", as:command, use:"bin/{histuniq,color}"
zplug "tcnksm/docker-alias", use:zshrc
zplug "k4rthik/git-cal", as:command, frozen:1
zplug "lib/clipboard", from:oh-my-zsh, if:"[[ $OSTYPE == *darwin* ]]"
zplug "jhawthorn/fzy", as:command, rename-to:fzy, hook-build:"make && sudo make install"
zplug "b4b4r07/enhancd", at:v1
zplug "mollifier/anyframe", at:4c23cb60
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-syntax-highlighting", defer:2
zplug "~/.zsh", from:local

# „Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥„ÅÆ„Ç§„É≥„Çπ„Éà„Éº„É´
if ! zplug check --verbose; then
  printf "Install? [y/N]: "
  if read -q; then
    echo
    zplug install
  fi
fi

zplug load

# „Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„ÉâË®≠ÂÆö
bindkey '\eOA' history-substring-search-up
bindkey '\eOB' history-substring-search-down
bindkey '^p' history-beginning-search-backward-end
bindkey '^n' history-beginning-search-forward-end
bindkey '^[[A' up-line-or-search
bindkey '^[[B' down-line-or-search

# Â±•Ê≠¥Ê§úÁ¥¢„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
autoload history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-backward-end history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-forward-end history-search-end

# Rust
if [ -d $HOME/.cargo ]; then
  source $HOME/.cargo/env
fi

# Aliases
if [ -f $HOME/.aliases ]; then
  . $HOME/.aliases
fi

# Python (pyenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.pyenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.pyenv/shims:$PATH"
fi

export PATH=${0:A:h}/bin:$PATH

# direnv
eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"

# SSHË£úÂÆå
function _ssh {
  compadd $(fgrep 'Host ' ~/.ssh/*.config | awk '{print $2}' | sort)
}

# poetry
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"


# Node.js (nodenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.nodenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.nodenv/bin:$PATH"
  eval "$(nodenv init -)"
fi

# atuin („Ç∑„Çß„É´Â±•Ê≠¥ÁÆ°ÁêÜ)
if [ -f $HOME/.cargo/bin/atuin ]; then
  eval "$(atuin init zsh)"
fi

# „Éë„ÇπË®≠ÂÆö
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/libpq/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/mysql-client/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/openjdk@17/bin:$PATH"

# jenv
export PATH="$HOME/.jenv/bin:$PATH"
eval "$(jenv init -)"


# SDKMAN
export SDKMAN_DIR="$HOME/.sdkman"
[[ -s "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh" ]] && source "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh"

# asdf
. /opt/homebrew/opt/asdf/libexec/asdf.sh

export DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH="$HOME/.local/lib:$DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH"

# opencode
export PATH="$HOME/.opencode/bin:$PATH"

# bun completions
[ -s "$HOME/.bun/_bun" ] && source "$HOME/.bun/_bun"

# bun
export BUN_INSTALL="$HOME/.bun"
export PATH="$BUN_INSTALL/bin:$PATH"

# Google Cloud SDK
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/path.zsh.inc"
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/completion.zsh.inc"

# claude-mem (memory service for Claude Code)
alias claude-mem="$BUN_INSTALL/bin/bun $HOME/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/thedotmack/plugin/scripts/worker-service.cjs"

content.thinking:
The user wants several enhancements to the prompt:

1. Color for the git branch name
2. Git status indicators (like + for changes, etc.)
3. Color for the working directory
4. Random gradient color assigned per tab

Let me think about this. For zsh prompts:

1. Branch color - easy with `%F{color}`
2. Git status indicators - can be done with vcs_info's `stagedstr`, `unstagedstr`, and `check-for-changes`
3. Directory color - easy with `%F{color}`
4. Random gradient per tab - this is interesting. We can generate a random color on shell startup and use it. For "gradient" effect, we could use multiple shades. In modern terminals that support 256 colors or truecolor, we can generate a random hue and create a gradient.


For the random gradient per tab, I'll generate a random base hue when the shell starts and apply varying lightness or saturation across different prompt elements using 256-color or truecolor codes. I could create a true gradient by shifting the color for each character in the directory path, though a simpler approach would be picking a random color from a curated palette for the directory itself.

Now I'm thinking through the implementation: I'll pick a random hue on startup, convert HSL to RGB for truecolor support, apply a gradient effect to the directory path by shifting the hue across characters, use a fixed color for the branch name (green for clean, yellow for dirty), and add git status indicators. Since the user is on Wezterm which supports truecolor, I'll need to write an HSL to RGB conversion function...

Writing the color conversion logic... I'm realizing that using a precmd hook to set a gradient-colored directory variable would be more practical than regenerating the prompt dynamically, and I can leverage zsh's vcs_info with change detection to show git status indicators alongside the directory path.

Writing HSL to RGB conversion... Writing the HSL-to-RGB conversion... Completing the hue-to-RGB conversion logic...

Now I'm building a function that takes the current directory path and applies a gradient of colors across each character, calculating the hue shift for each position and converting it to RGB values for the terminal output.

Setting up the prompt hook to refresh the gradient directory display before each command, and configuring git integration to show branch info and file status with color coding for staged and unstaged changes.

Now I'm refining the color conversion logic to handle float modulo operations correctly in zsh, using `fmod()` instead of the `%` operator for floating-point values.

I need to verify that the `%{...%}` escape sequences stored in the `_PROMPT_DIR` variable will be properly interpreted when expanded in the prompt‚Äîwith `PROMPT_SUBST` enabled, the variable expands first and then the prompt system should parse the escape codes correctly.

For the git status indicators, I'm thinking through how to display staged changes, unstaged changes, and untracked files. The built-in vcs_info features handle the first two with `check-for-changes true`, but I'll need to add a custom hook to detect untracked files since vcs_info doesn't cover that natively.

Setting up the vcs_info configuration with the necessary hooks...

Now I'm implementing a gradient prompt color that varies per session by generating a random hue value, then converting it to RGB using the HSL color model with fixed saturation and lightness values.

Converting hue to RGB... Writing shell script logic... Completing the untracked files check and then setting up the prompt to call vcs_info on each command, with the directory gradient being recalculated each time.

Now I'm reconsidering the performance implications of the gradient function‚Äîcalling it for every character in the path could add up, especially with the repeated `_hue2rgb` invocations, though since `printf` is a zsh builtin it shouldn't fork and the overhead should stay reasonable.

I'm thinking about whether to optimize with pre-computed colors or simpler segmented gradients, but the user specifically wants a smooth gradient effect, so character-by-character is the right approach. I should also account for edge cases like `%` characters in directory names and verify that `fmod` works as expected.

For the hue spread, I'm settling on 50 degrees to create a noticeable but not extreme gradient across the color wheel. Now I need to finalize the implementation plan: remove the old vcs_info setup and add the new gradient prompt with git status integration after zplug loads.

file.content:
# Âü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
export LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
export EDITOR=vim
export SAVEHIST=100000

# „Éó„É≠„É≥„Éó„ÉàË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Ç´„É¨„É≥„Éà„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ + git„Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç„ÅÆ„ÅøÔºâ
autoload -Uz vcs_info
precmd() { vcs_info }
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' formats ' (%b)'
setopt PROMPT_SUBST
PROMPT='%~${vcs_info_msg_0_} $ '

# To Enable Ctrl+a, Ctrl+e
bindkey -e

# zplug„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
source ~/.zplug/init.zsh

# ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-completions"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-history-substring-search"
zplug "Jxck/dotfiles", as:command, use:"bin/{histuniq,color}"
zplug "tcnksm/docker-alias", use:zshrc
zplug "k4rthik/git-cal", as:command, frozen:1
zplug "lib/clipboard", from:oh-my-zsh, if:"[[ $OSTYPE == *darwin* ]]"
zplug "jhawthorn/fzy", as:command, rename-to:fzy, hook-build:"make && sudo make install"
zplug "b4b4r07/enhancd", at:v1
zplug "mollifier/anyframe", at:4c23cb60
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-syntax-highlighting", defer:2
# git-prompt.zsh „ÅØ‰∏çË¶ÅÔºàvcs_info „Åß„Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç„ÇíË°®Á§∫Ôºâ
# zplug "~/.zsh", from:local

# „Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥„ÅÆ„Ç§„É≥„Çπ„Éà„Éº„É´
if ! zplug check --verbose; then
  printf "Install? [y/N]: "
  if read -q; then
    echo
    zplug install
  fi
fi

zplug load

# „Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„ÉâË®≠ÂÆö
bindkey '\eOA' history-substring-search-up
bindkey '\eOB' history-substring-search-down
bindkey '^p' history-beginning-search-backward-end
bindkey '^n' history-beginning-search-forward-end
bindkey '^[[A' up-line-or-search
bindkey '^[[B' down-line-or-search

# Â±•Ê≠¥Ê§úÁ¥¢„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
autoload history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-backward-end history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-forward-end history-search-end

# Rust
if [ -d $HOME/.cargo ]; then
  source $HOME/.cargo/env
fi

# Aliases
if [ -f $HOME/.aliases ]; then
  . $HOME/.aliases
fi

# Python (pyenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.pyenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.pyenv/shims:$PATH"
fi

export PATH=${0:A:h}/bin:$PATH

# direnv
eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"

# SSHË£úÂÆå
function _ssh {
  compadd $(fgrep 'Host ' ~/.ssh/*.config | awk '{print $2}' | sort)
}

# poetry
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"


# Node.js (nodenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.nodenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.nodenv/bin:$PATH"
  eval "$(nodenv init -)"
fi

# atuin („Ç∑„Çß„É´Â±•Ê≠¥ÁÆ°ÁêÜ)
if [ -f $HOME/.cargo/bin/atuin ]; then
  eval "$(atuin init zsh)"
fi

# „Éë„ÇπË®≠ÂÆö
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/libpq/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/mysql-client/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/openjdk@17/bin:$PATH"

# jenv
export PATH="$HOME/.jenv/bin:$PATH"
eval "$(jenv init -)"


# SDKMAN
export SDKMAN_DIR="$HOME/.sdkman"
[[ -s "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh" ]] && source "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh"

# asdf
. /opt/homebrew/opt/asdf/libexec/asdf.sh

export DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH="$HOME/.local/lib:$DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH"

# opencode
export PATH="$HOME/.opencode/bin:$PATH"

# bun completions
[ -s "$HOME/.bun/_bun" ] && source "$HOME/.bun/_bun"

# bun
export BUN_INSTALL="$HOME/.bun"
export PATH="$BUN_INSTALL/bin:$PATH"

# Google Cloud SDK
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/path.zsh.inc"
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/completion.zsh.inc"

# claude-mem (memory service for Claude Code)
alias claude-mem="$BUN_INSTALL/bin/bun $HOME/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/thedotmack/plugin/scripts/worker-service.cjs"

input.old_string:
# „Éó„É≠„É≥„Éó„ÉàË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Ç´„É¨„É≥„Éà„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ + git„Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç„ÅÆ„ÅøÔºâ
autoload -Uz vcs_info
precmd() { vcs_info }
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' formats ' (%b)'
setopt PROMPT_SUBST

input.new_string:
# „Éó„É≠„É≥„Éó„ÉàË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ªò„Åç„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ + git „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅ/„Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„ÇπÔºâ
zmodload zsh/mathfunc
autoload -Uz vcs_info add-zsh-hook

# „Çø„Éñ„Åî„Å®„Å´„É©„É≥„ÉÄ„É†„Å™Âü∫Ê∫ñËâ≤„ÇíÂâ≤„ÇäÂΩì„Å¶Ôºà0-360 „ÅÆËâ≤Áõ∏Ôºâ
_PROMPT_HUE=$((RANDOM % 360))

# HSL „ÅÆËâ≤Áõ∏„Çí truecolor „Ç®„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„ÉóÁî® R;G;B „Å´Â§âÊèõÔºàS=70%, L=65% Âõ∫ÂÆöÔºâ
_hue2rgb() {
  local -F h=$1 s=0.70 l=0.65
  local -F c=$(( (1.0 - fabs(2.0 * l - 1.0)) * s ))
  local -F hp=$(( h / 60.0 ))
  local -F x=$(( c * (1.0 - fabs(fmod(hp, 2.0) - 1.0)) ))
  local -F m=$(( l - c / 2.0 ))
  local -F r=0 g=0 b=0
  if   (( hp < 1 )); then r=$c; g=$x
  elif (( hp < 2 )); then r=$x; g=$c
  elif (( hp < 3 )); then g=$c; b=$x
  elif (( hp < 4 )); then g=$x; b=$c
  elif (( hp < 5 )); then r=$x; b=$c
  else                     r=$c; b=$x
  fi
  REPLY="$(( int((r+m)*255) ));$(( int((g+m)*255) ));$(( int((b+m)*255) ))"
}

# „Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ÊñáÂ≠óÂàó„Çí„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅßÁùÄËâ≤
_gradient_dir() {
  local dir="${(%):-%~}"
  local -i len=${#dir}
  local -F step=$(( len > 1 ? 50.0 / len : 0 ))
  _PROMPT_DIR=""
  for (( i = 1; i <= len; i++ )); do
    _hue2rgb $(( fmod(_PROMPT_HUE + (i-1) * step, 360.0) ))
    _PROMPT_DIR+="%{\e[38;2;${REPLY}m%}${dir[$i]}"
  done
  _PROMPT_DIR+="%f"
}

# vcs_info: git „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç + „Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„ÇπË°®Á§∫
zstyle ':vcs_info:*' enable git
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' check-for-changes true
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' stagedstr '%F{green}+'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' unstagedstr '%F{yellow}!'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' formats ' %F{cyan}(%F{blue}%b%c%u%m%F{cyan})%f'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' actionformats ' %F{cyan}(%F{blue}%b%F{cyan}|%F{red}%a%c%u%m%F{cyan})%f'

# untracked „Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÅÆÊ§úÂá∫Ôºà? Ë°®Á§∫Ôºâ
zstyle ':vcs_info:git*+set-message:*' hooks git-untracked
+vi-git-untracked() {
  if [[ $(command git rev-parse --is-inside-work-tree 2>/dev/null) == 'true' ]] \
     && command git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null | command grep -q '^??'; then
    hook_com[misc]='%F{red}?'
  fi
}

_prompt_precmd() {
  vcs_info
  _gradient_dir
}
add-zsh-hook precmd _prompt_precmd

setopt PROMPT_SUBST
PROMPT='${_PROMPT_DIR}${vcs_info_msg_0_} $ '

input.command:
git add .zshrc && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
feat: Add gradient directory color and git status indicators

- Directory path is colored with a truecolor gradient using a random
  hue assigned per tab/session (hsl2rgb with zsh/mathfunc)
- Git branch shown in blue with status indicators:
  + (green) = staged changes
  ! (yellow) = unstaged changes
  ? (red) = untracked files
- Rebase/merge action shown in red when applicable

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)" && git push

PR #28 „ÇíÊõ¥Êñ∞„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇÊñ∞„Åó„ÅÑ„Çø„Éº„Éü„Éä„É´„Çø„Éñ„ÇíÈñã„ÅÑ„Å¶Á¢∫Ë™ç„Åó„Å¶„Åø„Å¶„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ

## ÂÆüË£ÖÂÜÖÂÆπ

**„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ªò„Åç„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™:**
- „Çø„Éñ„ÇíÈñã„Åè„Åü„Å≥„Å´ 0-360 „ÅÆ„É©„É≥„ÉÄ„É†„Å™Ëâ≤Áõ∏„ÅåÂâ≤„ÇäÂΩì„Å¶„Çâ„Çå„Çã
- „Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÅÆ„Éë„ÇπÊñáÂ≠óÂàó„Å´ÂØæ„Åó„Å¶ 50Â∫¶„ÅÆÁØÑÂõ≤„Åß„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÇíÈÅ©Áî®

The escape sequences are being displayed literally instead of being interpreted. The issue is that `%{\e[38;2;...m%}` in the PROMPT variable isn't being processed correctly. 

The problem is that `\e` escape sequences inside `%{...%}` don't get expanded in zsh prompts. I need to use `$'\e'` or `\033` or use `print -P` approach, or use the `$'...'` quoting.

Actually, the real issue is that when building the string in `_PROMPT_DIR`, the `\e` is stored as a literal backslash-e, not as the actual escape character. I need to use `$'\e'` in the string construction, or use `\033`, or use printf to generate the actual escape character.


I'm trying to fix this by using `$'\e'` to properly generate the escape character within the prompt string, but I'm running into issues with how to properly quote and concatenate the escape sequences with the color values.

The cleanest approach is to pre-define a variable holding the actual escape character, then reference it when building the prompt string. This way the escape character gets properly expanded at runtime rather than being treated as a literal string.

# Âü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
export LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
export EDITOR=vim
export SAVEHIST=100000

# „Éó„É≠„É≥„Éó„ÉàË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ªò„Åç„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ + git „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅ/„Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„ÇπÔºâ
zmodload zsh/mathfunc
autoload -Uz vcs_info add-zsh-hook

# „Çø„Éñ„Åî„Å®„Å´„É©„É≥„ÉÄ„É†„Å™Âü∫Ê∫ñËâ≤„ÇíÂâ≤„ÇäÂΩì„Å¶Ôºà0-360 „ÅÆËâ≤Áõ∏Ôºâ
_PROMPT_HUE=$((RANDOM % 360))

# HSL „ÅÆËâ≤Áõ∏„Çí truecolor „Ç®„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„ÉóÁî® R;G;B „Å´Â§âÊèõÔºàS=70%, L=65% Âõ∫ÂÆöÔºâ
_hue2rgb() {
  local -F h=$1 s=0.70 l=0.65
  local -F c=$(( (1.0 - fabs(2.0 * l - 1.0)) * s ))
  local -F hp=$(( h / 60.0 ))
  local -F x=$(( c * (1.0 - fabs(fmod(hp, 2.0) - 1.0)) ))
  local -F m=$(( l - c / 2.0 ))
  local -F r=0 g=0 b=0
  if   (( hp < 1 )); then r=$c; g=$x
  elif (( hp < 2 )); then r=$x; g=$c
  elif (( hp < 3 )); then g=$c; b=$x
  elif (( hp < 4 )); then g=$x; b=$c
  elif (( hp < 5 )); then r=$x; b=$c
  else                     r=$c; b=$x
  fi
  REPLY="$(( int((r+m)*255) ));$(( int((g+m)*255) ));$(( int((b+m)*255) ))"
}

# „Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ÊñáÂ≠óÂàó„Çí„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅßÁùÄËâ≤
_gradient_dir() {
  local dir="${(%):-%~}"
  local -i len=${#dir}
  local -F step=$(( len > 1 ? 50.0 / len : 0 ))
  _PROMPT_DIR=""
  for (( i = 1; i <= len; i++ )); do
    _hue2rgb $(( fmod(_PROMPT_HUE + (i-1) * step, 360.0) ))
    _PROMPT_DIR+="%{\e[38;2;${REPLY}m%}${dir[$i]}"
  done
  _PROMPT_DIR+="%f"
}

# vcs_info: git „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç + „Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„ÇπË°®Á§∫
zstyle ':vcs_info:*' enable git
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' check-for-changes true
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' stagedstr '%F{green}+'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' unstagedstr '%F{yellow}!'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' formats ' %F{cyan}(%F{blue}%b%c%u%m%F{cyan})%f'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' actionformats ' %F{cyan}(%F{blue}%b%F{cyan}|%F{red}%a%c%u%m%F{cyan})%f'

# untracked „Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÅÆÊ§úÂá∫Ôºà? Ë°®Á§∫Ôºâ
zstyle ':vcs_info:git*+set-message:*' hooks git-untracked
+vi-git-untracked() {
  if [[ $(command git rev-parse --is-inside-work-tree 2>/dev/null) == 'true' ]] \
     && command git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null | command grep -q '^??'; then
    hook_com[misc]='%F{red}?'
  fi
}

_prompt_precmd() {
  vcs_info
  _gradient_dir

add-zsh-hook precmd _prompt_precmd

# Âü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
export LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
export EDITOR=vim
export SAVEHIST=100000

# „Éó„É≠„É≥„Éó„ÉàË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ªò„Åç„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ + git „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅ/„Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„ÇπÔºâ
zmodload zsh/mathfunc
autoload -Uz vcs_info add-zsh-hook

# „Çø„Éñ„Åî„Å®„Å´„É©„É≥„ÉÄ„É†„Å™Âü∫Ê∫ñËâ≤„ÇíÂâ≤„ÇäÂΩì„Å¶Ôºà0-360 „ÅÆËâ≤Áõ∏Ôºâ
_PROMPT_HUE=$((RANDOM % 360))

# HSL „ÅÆËâ≤Áõ∏„Çí truecolor „Ç®„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„ÉóÁî® R;G;B „Å´Â§âÊèõÔºàS=70%, L=65% Âõ∫ÂÆöÔºâ
_hue2rgb() {
  local -F h=$1 s=0.70 l=0.65
  local -F c=$(( (1.0 - fabs(2.0 * l - 1.0)) * s ))
  local -F hp=$(( h / 60.0 ))
  local -F x=$(( c * (1.0 - fabs(fmod(hp, 2.0) - 1.0)) ))
  local -F m=$(( l - c / 2.0 ))
  local -F r=0 g=0 b=0
  if   (( hp < 1 )); then r=$c; g=$x
  elif (( hp < 2 )); then r=$x; g=$c
  elif (( hp < 3 )); then g=$c; b=$x
  elif (( hp < 4 )); then g=$x; b=$c
  elif (( hp < 5 )); then r=$x; b=$c
  else                     r=$c; b=$x
  fi
  REPLY="$(( int((r+m)*255) ));$(( int((g+m)*255) ));$(( int((b+m)*255) ))"
}

# „Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ÊñáÂ≠óÂàó„Çí„Ç∞„É©„Éá„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅßÁùÄËâ≤
_gradient_dir() {
  local dir="${(%):-%~}"
  local -i len=${#dir}
  local -F step=$(( len > 1 ? 50.0 / len : 0 ))
  local esc=$'\e'
  _PROMPT_DIR=""
  for (( i = 1; i <= len; i++ )); do
    _hue2rgb $(( fmod(_PROMPT_HUE + (i-1) * step, 360.0) ))
    _PROMPT_DIR+="%{${esc}[38;2;${REPLY}m%}${dir[$i]}"
  done
  _PROMPT_DIR+="%f"
}

# vcs_info: git „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç + „Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„ÇπË°®Á§∫
zstyle ':vcs_info:*' enable git
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' check-for-changes true
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' stagedstr '%F{green}+'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' unstagedstr '%F{yellow}!'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' formats ' %F{cyan}(%F{blue}%b%c%u%m%F{cyan})%f'
zstyle ':vcs_info:git:*' actionformats ' %F{cyan}(%F{blue}%b%F{cyan}|%F{red}%a%c%u%m%F{cyan})%f'

# untracked „Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÅÆÊ§úÂá∫Ôºà? Ë°®Á§∫Ôºâ
zstyle ':vcs_info:git*+set-message:*' hooks git-untracked
+vi-git-untracked() {
  if [[ $(command git rev-parse --is-inside-work-tree 2>/dev/null) == 'true' ]] \
     && command git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null | command grep -q '^??'; then
    hook_com[misc]='%F{red}?'
  fi
}

_prompt_precmd() {
  vcs_info
  _gradient_dir
}
add-zsh-hook precmd _prompt_precmd

setopt PROMPT_SUBST
PROMPT='${_PROMPT_DIR}${vcs_info_msg_0_} $ '

# To Enable Ctrl+a, Ctrl+e
bindkey -e

# zplug„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
source ~/.zplug/init.zsh

# ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-completions"
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-history-substring-search"
zplug "Jxck/dotfiles", as:command, use:"bin/{histuniq,color}"
zplug "tcnksm/docker-alias", use:zshrc
zplug "k4rthik/git-cal", as:command, frozen:1
zplug "lib/clipboard", from:oh-my-zsh, if:"[[ $OSTYPE == *darwin* ]]"
zplug "jhawthorn/fzy", as:command, rename-to:fzy, hook-build:"make && sudo make install"
zplug "b4b4r07/enhancd", at:v1
zplug "mollifier/anyframe", at:4c23cb60
zplug "zsh-users/zsh-syntax-highlighting", defer:2
# git-prompt.zsh „ÅØ‰∏çË¶ÅÔºàvcs_info „Åß„Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç„ÇíË°®Á§∫Ôºâ
# zplug "~/.zsh", from:local

# „Éó„É©„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥„ÅÆ„Ç§„É≥„Çπ„Éà„Éº„É´
if ! zplug check --verbose; then
  printf "Install? [y/N]: "
  if read -q; then
    echo
    zplug install
  fi
fi

zplug load

# „Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„ÉâË®≠ÂÆö
bindkey '\eOA' history-substring-search-up
bindkey '\eOB' history-substring-search-down
bindkey '^p' history-beginning-search-backward-end
bindkey '^n' history-beginning-search-forward-end
bindkey '^[[A' up-line-or-search
bindkey '^[[B' down-line-or-search

# Â±•Ê≠¥Ê§úÁ¥¢„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö
autoload history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-backward-end history-search-end
zle -N history-beginning-search-forward-end history-search-end

# Rust
if [ -d $HOME/.cargo ]; then
  source $HOME/.cargo/env
fi

# Aliases
if [ -f $HOME/.aliases ]; then
  . $HOME/.aliases
fi

# Python (pyenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.pyenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.pyenv/shims:$PATH"
fi

export PATH=${0:A:h}/bin:$PATH

# direnv
eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"

# SSHË£úÂÆå
function _ssh {
  compadd $(fgrep 'Host ' ~/.ssh/*.config | awk '{print $2}' | sort)
}

# poetry
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"


# Node.js (nodenv)
if [ -d $HOME/.nodenv ]; then
  export PATH="$HOME/.nodenv/bin:$PATH"
  eval "$(nodenv init -)"
fi

# atuin („Ç∑„Çß„É´Â±•Ê≠¥ÁÆ°ÁêÜ)
if [ -f $HOME/.cargo/bin/atuin ]; then
  eval "$(atuin init zsh)"
fi

# „Éë„ÇπË®≠ÂÆö
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/libpq/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/mysql-client/bin:$PATH"
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/openjdk@17/bin:$PATH"

# jenv

# SDKMAN
export SDKMAN_DIR="$HOME/.sdkman"

# asdf
. /opt/homebrew/opt/asdf/libexec/asdf.sh

export DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH="$HOME/.local/lib:$DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH"

# opencode
export PATH="$HOME/.opencode/bin:$PATH"

# bun completions
[ -s "$HOME/.bun/_bun" ] && source "$HOME/.bun/_bun"

# bun
export BUN_INSTALL="$HOME/.bun"
export PATH="$BUN_INSTALL/bin:$PATH"

# Google Cloud SDK
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/path.zsh.inc"
source "/opt/homebrew/share/google-cloud-sdk/completion.zsh.inc"

# claude-mem (memory service for Claude Code)
alias claude-mem="$BUN_INSTALL/bin/bun $HOME/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/thedotmack/plugin/scripts/worker-service.cjs"

   457‚Üí#  Default: {}

   460‚Üí## Supply overrides for terminado. Currently only supports "shell_command". On

   489‚Üí## Jupyter„Éé„Éº„Éà„Éñ„ÉÉ„ÇØ„Åå‰ΩøÁî®„Åô„Çã tornado.web.Application „ÅÆ„Ç™„Éº„Éê„Éº„É©„Ç§„Éâ„ÇíÊåáÂÆö„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

   492‚Üí
   493‚Üí## X-Scheme/X-Forwarded-Proto „Åä„Çà„Å≥ X-Real-Ip/X-Forwarded-For
   494‚Üí#  „Éò„ÉÉ„ÉÄ„Éº„Åå„Ç¢„ÉÉ„Éó„Çπ„Éà„É™„Éº„É†„ÅÆ„É™„Éê„Éº„Çπ„Éó„É≠„Ç≠„Ç∑„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶ÈÄÅ‰ø°„Åï„Çå„Åü„Åì„Å®„Çí‰ø°È†º„Åô„Çã„Åã„Å©„ÅÜ„Åã„ÄÇ„Éó„É≠„Ç≠„Ç∑„Åå SSL „ÇíÂá¶ÁêÜ„Åô„ÇãÂ†¥Âêà„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å®„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ
   495‚Üí#  Default: False

   497‚Üí
   498‚Üí## Disable launching browser by redirect file
   499‚Üí#  
   500‚Üí#  For versions of notebook > 5.7.2, a security feature measure was added that
   501‚Üí#  prevented the authentication token used to launch the browser from being
   502‚Üí#  visible. This feature makes it difficult for other users on a multi-user
   503‚Üí#  system from running code in your Jupyter session as you.
   504‚Üí#  
   505‚Üí#  However, some environments (like Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) and
   506‚Üí#  Chromebooks), launching a browser using a redirect file can lead the browser
   507‚Üí#  failing to load. This is because of the difference in file structures/paths
   508‚Üí#  between the runtime and the browser.
   509‚Üí#  
   510‚Üí#  Disabling this setting to False will disable this behavior, allowing the
   511‚Üí#  browser to launch by using a URL and visible token (as before).
   512‚Üí#  Default: True

   535‚Üí#

   547‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   548‚Üí# ConnectionFileMixin(LoggingConfigurable) configuration

   551‚Üí

   647‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   648‚Üí# Session(Configurable) configuration
   649‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   650‚Üí## Object for handling serialization and sending of messages.
   651‚Üí#  
   652‚Üí#  The Session object handles building messages and sending them with ZMQ sockets
   653‚Üí#  or ZMQStream objects.  Objects can communicate with each other over the
   654‚Üí#  network via Session objects, and only need to work with the dict-based IPython
   655‚Üí#  message spec. The Session will handle serialization/deserialization, security,
   656‚Üí#  and metadata.
   657‚Üí#  
   658‚Üí#  Sessions support configurable serialization via packer/unpacker traits, and
   659‚Üí#  signing with HMAC digests via the key/keyfile traits.
   660‚Üí#  
   661‚Üí#  Parameters ----------
   662‚Üí#  
   663‚Üí#  debug : bool
   664‚Üí#      whether to trigger extra debugging statements
   665‚Üí#  packer/unpacker : str : 'json', 'pickle' or import_string
   666‚Üí#      importstrings for methods to serialize message parts.  If just
   667‚Üí#      'json' or 'pickle', predefined JSON and pickle packers will be used.
   668‚Üí#      Otherwise, the entire importstring must be used.
   669‚Üí#  
   670‚Üí#      The functions must accept at least valid JSON input, and output *bytes*.
   671‚Üí#  
   672‚Üí#      For example, to use msgpack:
   673‚Üí#      packer = 'msgpack.packb', unpacker='msgpack.unpackb'
   674‚Üí#  pack/unpack : callables
   675‚Üí#      You can also set the pack/unpack callables for serialization directly.
   676‚Üí#  session : bytes
   677‚Üí#      the ID of this Session object.  The default is to generate a new UUID.
   678‚Üí#  username : unicode
   679‚Üí#      username added to message headers.  The default is to ask the OS.
   680‚Üí#  key : bytes
   681‚Üí#      The key used to initialize an HMAC signature.  If unset, messages
   682‚Üí#      will not be signed or checked.
   683‚Üí#  keyfile : filepath
   684‚Üí#      The file containing a key.  If this is set, `key` will be initialized
   685‚Üí#      to the contents of the file.
   686‚Üí
   687‚Üí## Threshold (in bytes) beyond which an object's buffer should be extracted to
   688‚Üí#  avoid pickling.
   689‚Üí#  Default: 1024
   690‚Üí# c.Session.buffer_threshold = 1024
   691‚Üí
   692‚Üí## Whether to check PID to protect against calls after fork.
   693‚Üí#  
   694‚Üí#  This check can be disabled if fork-safety is handled elsewhere.
   695‚Üí#  Default: True
   696‚Üí# c.Session.check_pid = True
   697‚Üí
   698‚Üí## Threshold (in bytes) beyond which a buffer should be sent without copying.
   699‚Üí#  Default: 65536
   700‚Üí# c.Session.copy_threshold = 65536
   701‚Üí
   702‚Üí## Debug output in the Session
   703‚Üí#  Default: False
   704‚Üí# c.Session.debug = False
   705‚Üí
   706‚Üí## The maximum number of digests to remember.
   707‚Üí#  
   708‚Üí#  The digest history will be culled when it exceeds this value.
   709‚Üí#  Default: 65536
   710‚Üí# c.Session.digest_history_size = 65536
   711‚Üí
   712‚Üí## The maximum number of items for a container to be introspected for custom
   713‚Üí#  serialization. Containers larger than this are pickled outright.
   714‚Üí#  Default: 64
   715‚Üí# c.Session.item_threshold = 64
   716‚Üí
   717‚Üí## execution key, for signing messages.
   718‚Üí#  Default: b''
   719‚Üí# c.Session.key = b''
   720‚Üí
   721‚Üí## path to file containing execution key.
   722‚Üí#  Default: ''
   723‚Üí# c.Session.keyfile = ''
   724‚Üí
   725‚Üí## Metadata dictionary, which serves as the default top-level metadata dict for
   726‚Üí#  each message.
   727‚Üí#  Default: {}
   728‚Üí# c.Session.metadata = {}
   729‚Üí
   730‚Üí## The name of the packer for serializing messages. Should be one of 'json',
   731‚Üí#  'pickle', or an import name for a custom callable serializer.
   732‚Üí#  Default: 'json'
   733‚Üí# c.Session.packer = 'json'
   734‚Üí
   735‚Üí## The UUID identifying this session.
   736‚Üí#  Default: ''
   737‚Üí# c.Session.session = ''
   738‚Üí
   739‚Üí## The digest scheme used to construct the message signatures. Must have the form
   740‚Üí#  'hmac-HASH'.
   741‚Üí#  Default: 'hmac-sha256'
   742‚Üí# c.Session.signature_scheme = 'hmac-sha256'
   743‚Üí
   744‚Üí## The name of the unpacker for unserializing messages. Only used with custom
   745‚Üí#  functions for `packer`.
   746‚Üí#  Default: 'json'
   747‚Üí# c.Session.unpacker = 'json'
   748‚Üí
   749‚Üí## Username for the Session. Default is your system username.
   750‚Üí#  Default: 'wonder'
   751‚Üí# c.Session.username = 'wonder'
   752‚Üí
   753‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   754‚Üí# MultiKernelManager(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
   755‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   756‚Üí## A class for managing multiple kernels.
   757‚Üí
   758‚Üí## The name of the default kernel to start
   759‚Üí#  Default: 'python3'
   760‚Üí# c.MultiKernelManager.default_kernel_name = 'python3'
   761‚Üí
   762‚Üí## The kernel manager class.  This is configurable to allow subclassing of the
   763‚Üí#  KernelManager for customized behavior.
   764‚Üí#  Default: 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'
   765‚Üí# c.MultiKernelManager.kernel_manager_class = 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'
   766‚Üí
   767‚Üí## Share a single zmq.Context to talk to all my kernels
   768‚Üí#  Default: True
   769‚Üí# c.MultiKernelManager.shared_context = True
   770‚Üí
   771‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   772‚Üí# MappingKernelManager(MultiKernelManager) configuration
   773‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   774‚Üí## A KernelManager that handles notebook mapping and HTTP error handling
   775‚Üí
   776‚Üí## White list of allowed kernel message types. When the list is empty, all
   777‚Üí#  message types are allowed.
   778‚Üí#  Default: []
   779‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.allowed_message_types = []
   780‚Üí
   781‚Üí## Whether messages from kernels whose frontends have disconnected should be
   782‚Üí#  buffered in-memory. When True (default), messages are buffered and replayed on
   783‚Üí#  reconnect, avoiding lost messages due to interrupted connectivity. Disable if
   784‚Üí#  long-running kernels will produce too much output while no frontends are
   785‚Üí#  connected.
   786‚Üí#  Default: True
   787‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.buffer_offline_messages = True
   788‚Üí
   789‚Üí## Whether to consider culling kernels which are busy. Only effective if
   790‚Üí#  cull_idle_timeout > 0.
   791‚Üí#  Default: False
   792‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_busy = False
   793‚Üí
   794‚Üí## Whether to consider culling kernels which have one or more connections. Only
   795‚Üí#  effective if cull_idle_timeout > 0.
   796‚Üí#  Default: False
   797‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_connected = False
   798‚Üí
   799‚Üí## Timeout (in seconds) after which a kernel is considered idle and ready to be
   800‚Üí#  culled. Values of 0 or lower disable culling. Very short timeouts may result
   801‚Üí#  in kernels being culled for users with poor network connections.
   802‚Üí#  Default: 0
   803‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_idle_timeout = 0
   804‚Üí
   805‚Üí## The interval (in seconds) on which to check for idle kernels exceeding the
   806‚Üí#  cull timeout value.
   807‚Üí#  Default: 300
   808‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_interval = 300
   809‚Üí
   810‚Üí## The name of the default kernel to start
   811‚Üí#  See also: MultiKernelManager.default_kernel_name
   812‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.default_kernel_name = 'python3'
   813‚Üí
   814‚Üí## Timeout for giving up on a kernel (in seconds). On starting and restarting
   815‚Üí#  kernels, we check whether the kernel is running and responsive by sending
   816‚Üí#  kernel_info_requests. This sets the timeout in seconds for how long the kernel
   817‚Üí#  can take before being presumed dead. This affects the MappingKernelManager
   818‚Üí#  (which handles kernel restarts) and the ZMQChannelsHandler (which handles the
   819‚Üí#  startup).
   820‚Üí#  Default: 60
   821‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.kernel_info_timeout = 60
   822‚Üí
   823‚Üí## The kernel manager class.  This is configurable to allow
   824‚Üí#  See also: MultiKernelManager.kernel_manager_class
   825‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.kernel_manager_class = 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'
   826‚Üí
   827‚Üí#  Default: ''
   828‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.root_dir = ''
   829‚Üí
   830‚Üí## Share a single zmq.Context to talk to all my kernels
   831‚Üí#  See also: MultiKernelManager.shared_context
   832‚Üí# c.MappingKernelManager.shared_context = True
   833‚Üí
   834‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   835‚Üí# KernelSpecManager(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
   836‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   837‚Üí## If there is no Python kernelspec registered and the IPython kernel is
   838‚Üí#  available, ensure it is added to the spec list.
   839‚Üí#  Default: True
   840‚Üí# c.KernelSpecManager.ensure_native_kernel = True
   841‚Üí
   842‚Üí## The kernel spec class.  This is configurable to allow subclassing of the
   843‚Üí#  KernelSpecManager for customized behavior.
   844‚Üí#  Default: 'jupyter_client.kernelspec.KernelSpec'
   845‚Üí# c.KernelSpecManager.kernel_spec_class = 'jupyter_client.kernelspec.KernelSpec'
   846‚Üí
   847‚Üí## Whitelist of allowed kernel names.
   848‚Üí#  
   849‚Üí#  By default, all installed kernels are allowed.
   850‚Üí#  Default: set()
   851‚Üí# c.KernelSpecManager.whitelist = set()
   852‚Üí
   853‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   854‚Üí# ContentsManager(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
   855‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   856‚Üí## Base class for serving files and directories.
   857‚Üí#  
   858‚Üí#  This serves any text or binary file, as well as directories, with special
   859‚Üí#  handling for JSON notebook documents.
   860‚Üí#  
   861‚Üí#  Most APIs take a path argument, which is always an API-style unicode path, and
   862‚Üí#  always refers to a directory.
   863‚Üí#  
   864‚Üí#  - unicode, not url-escaped
   865‚Üí#  - '/'-separated
   866‚Üí#  - leading and trailing '/' will be stripped
   867‚Üí#  - if unspecified, path defaults to '',
   868‚Üí#    indicating the root path.
   869‚Üí
   870‚Üí## Allow access to hidden files
   871‚Üí#  Default: False
   872‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.allow_hidden = False
   873‚Üí
   874‚Üí#  Default: None
   875‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.checkpoints = None
   876‚Üí
   877‚Üí#  Default: 'notebook.services.contents.checkpoints.Checkpoints'
   878‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.checkpoints_class = 'notebook.services.contents.checkpoints.Checkpoints'
   879‚Üí
   880‚Üí#  Default: {}
   881‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.checkpoints_kwargs = {}
   882‚Üí
   883‚Üí## handler class to use when serving raw file requests.
   884‚Üí#  
   885‚Üí#  Default is a fallback that talks to the ContentsManager API, which may be
   886‚Üí#  inefficient, especially for large files.
   887‚Üí#  
   888‚Üí#  Local files-based ContentsManagers can use a StaticFileHandler subclass, which
   889‚Üí#  will be much more efficient.
   890‚Üí#  
   891‚Üí#  Access to these files should be Authenticated.
   892‚Üí#  Default: 'notebook.files.handlers.FilesHandler'
   893‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.files_handler_class = 'notebook.files.handlers.FilesHandler'
   894‚Üí
   895‚Üí## Extra parameters to pass to files_handler_class.
   896‚Üí#  
   897‚Üí#  For example, StaticFileHandlers generally expect a `path` argument specifying
   898‚Üí#  the root directory from which to serve files.
   899‚Üí#  Default: {}
   900‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.files_handler_params = {}
   901‚Üí
   902‚Üí## Glob patterns to hide in file and directory listings.
   903‚Üí#  Default: ['__pycache__', '*.pyc', '*.pyo', '.DS_Store', '*.so', '*.dylib', '*~']
   904‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.hide_globs = ['__pycache__', '*.pyc', '*.pyo', '.DS_Store', '*.so', '*.dylib', '*~']
   905‚Üí
   906‚Üí## Python callable or importstring thereof
   907‚Üí#  
   908‚Üí#  To be called on a contents model prior to save.
   909‚Üí#  
   910‚Üí#  This can be used to process the structure, such as removing notebook outputs
   911‚Üí#  or other side effects that should not be saved.
   912‚Üí#  
   913‚Üí#  It will be called as (all arguments passed by keyword)::
   914‚Üí#  
   915‚Üí#      hook(path=path, model=model, contents_manager=self)
   916‚Üí#  
   917‚Üí#  - model: the model to be saved. Includes file contents.
   918‚Üí#    Modifying this dict will affect the file that is stored.
   919‚Üí#  - path: the API path of the save destination
   920‚Üí#  - contents_manager: this ContentsManager instance
   921‚Üí#  Default: None
   922‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.pre_save_hook = None
   923‚Üí
   924‚Üí#  Default: '/'
   925‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.root_dir = '/'
   926‚Üí
   927‚Üí## The base name used when creating untitled directories.
   928‚Üí#  Default: 'Untitled Folder'
   929‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.untitled_directory = 'Untitled Folder'
   930‚Üí
   931‚Üí## The base name used when creating untitled files.
   932‚Üí#  Default: 'untitled'
   933‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.untitled_file = 'untitled'
   934‚Üí
   935‚Üí## The base name used when creating untitled notebooks.
   936‚Üí#  Default: 'Untitled'
   937‚Üí# c.ContentsManager.untitled_notebook = 'Untitled'
   938‚Üí
   939‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   940‚Üí# FileManagerMixin(Configurable) configuration
   941‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   942‚Üí## Mixin for ContentsAPI classes that interact with the filesystem.
   943‚Üí#  
   944‚Üí#  Provides facilities for reading, writing, and copying both notebooks and
   945‚Üí#  generic files.
   946‚Üí#  
   947‚Üí#  Shared by FileContentsManager and FileCheckpoints.
   948‚Üí#  
   949‚Üí#  Note ---- Classes using this mixin must provide the following attributes:
   950‚Üí#  
   951‚Üí#  root_dir : unicode
   952‚Üí#      A directory against against which API-style paths are to be resolved.
   953‚Üí#  
   954‚Üí#  log : logging.Logger
   955‚Üí
   956‚Üí## By default notebooks are saved on disk on a temporary file and then if
   957‚Üí#  successfully written, it replaces the old ones. This procedure, namely
   958‚Üí#  'atomic_writing', causes some bugs on file system without operation order
   959‚Üí#  enforcement (like some networked fs). If set to False, the new notebook is
   960‚Üí#  written directly on the old one which could fail (eg: full filesystem or quota
   961‚Üí#  )
   962‚Üí#  Default: True
   963‚Üí# c.FileManagerMixin.use_atomic_writing = True
   964‚Üí
   965‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   966‚Üí# FileContentsManager(FileManagerMixin, ContentsManager) configuration
   967‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   968‚Üí## Allow access to hidden files
   969‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.allow_hidden
   970‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.allow_hidden = False
   971‚Üí
   972‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.checkpoints
   973‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.checkpoints = None
   974‚Üí
   975‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.checkpoints_class
   976‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.checkpoints_class = 'notebook.services.contents.checkpoints.Checkpoints'
   977‚Üí
   978‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.checkpoints_kwargs
   979‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.checkpoints_kwargs = {}
   980‚Üí
   981‚Üí## If True (default), deleting files will send them to the platform's
   982‚Üí#  trash/recycle bin, where they can be recovered. If False, deleting files
   983‚Üí#  really deletes them.
   984‚Üí#  Default: True
   985‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.delete_to_trash = True
   986‚Üí
   987‚Üí## handler class to use when serving raw file requests.
   988‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.files_handler_class
   989‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.files_handler_class = 'notebook.files.handlers.FilesHandler'
   990‚Üí
   991‚Üí## Extra parameters to pass to files_handler_class.
   992‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.files_handler_params
   993‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.files_handler_params = {}
   994‚Üí
   995‚Üí## 
   996‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.hide_globs
   997‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.hide_globs = ['__pycache__', '*.pyc', '*.pyo', '.DS_Store', '*.so', '*.dylib', '*~']
   998‚Üí
   999‚Üí## Python callable or importstring thereof
  1000‚Üí#  
  1001‚Üí#  to be called on the path of a file just saved.
  1002‚Üí#  
  1003‚Üí#  This can be used to process the file on disk, such as converting the notebook
  1004‚Üí#  to a script or HTML via nbconvert.
  1005‚Üí#  
  1006‚Üí#  It will be called as (all arguments passed by keyword)::
  1007‚Üí#  
  1008‚Üí#      hook(os_path=os_path, model=model, contents_manager=instance)
  1009‚Üí#  
  1010‚Üí#  - path: the filesystem path to the file just written - model: the model
  1011‚Üí#  representing the file - contents_manager: this ContentsManager instance
  1012‚Üí#  Default: None
  1013‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.post_save_hook = None
  1014‚Üí
  1015‚Üí## Python callable or importstring thereof
  1016‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.pre_save_hook
  1017‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.pre_save_hook = None
  1018‚Üí
  1019‚Üí#  Default: ''
  1020‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.root_dir = ''
  1021‚Üí
  1022‚Üí## DEPRECATED, use post_save_hook. Will be removed in Notebook 5.0
  1023‚Üí#  Default: False
  1024‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.save_script = False
  1025‚Üí
  1026‚Üí## The base name used when creating untitled directories.
  1027‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.untitled_directory
  1028‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.untitled_directory = 'Untitled Folder'
  1029‚Üí
  1030‚Üí## The base name used when creating untitled files.
  1031‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.untitled_file
  1032‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.untitled_file = 'untitled'
  1033‚Üí
  1034‚Üí## The base name used when creating untitled notebooks.
  1035‚Üí#  See also: ContentsManager.untitled_notebook
  1036‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.untitled_notebook = 'Untitled'
  1037‚Üí
  1038‚Üí## By default notebooks are saved on disk on a temporary file and then if
  1039‚Üí#  successfully written, it replaces the old ones.
  1040‚Üí#  See also: FileManagerMixin.use_atomic_writing
  1041‚Üí# c.FileContentsManager.use_atomic_writing = True
  1042‚Üí
  1043‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1044‚Üí# NotebookNotary(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
  1045‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1046‚Üí## A class for computing and verifying notebook signatures.
  1047‚Üí
  1048‚Üí## The hashing algorithm used to sign notebooks.
  1049‚Üí#  Choices: any of ['sha384', 'sha3_512', 'sha256', 'blake2s', 'md5', 'sha3_224', 'sha224', 'sha1', 'blake2b', 'sha3_384', 'sha512', 'sha3_256']
  1050‚Üí#  Default: 'sha256'
  1051‚Üí# c.NotebookNotary.algorithm = 'sha256'
  1052‚Üí
  1053‚Üí## The sqlite file in which to store notebook signatures. By default, this will
  1054‚Üí#  be in your Jupyter data directory. You can set it to ':memory:' to disable
  1055‚Üí#  sqlite writing to the filesystem.
  1056‚Üí#  Default: ''
  1057‚Üí# c.NotebookNotary.db_file = ''
  1058‚Üí
  1059‚Üí## The secret key with which notebooks are signed.
  1060‚Üí#  Default: b''
  1061‚Üí# c.NotebookNotary.secret = b''
  1062‚Üí
  1063‚Üí## The file where the secret key is stored.
  1064‚Üí#  Default: ''
  1065‚Üí# c.NotebookNotary.secret_file = ''
  1066‚Üí
  1067‚Üí## A callable returning the storage backend for notebook signatures. The default
  1068‚Üí#  uses an SQLite database.
  1069‚Üí#  Default: traitlets.Undefined
  1070‚Üí# c.NotebookNotary.store_factory = traitlets.Undefined
  1071‚Üí
  1072‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1073‚Üí# GatewayKernelManager(MappingKernelManager) configuration

  1075‚Üí## Kernel manager that supports remote kernels hosted by Jupyter Kernel or

  1080‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.allowed_message_types = []

  1082‚Üí## Whether messages from kernels whose frontends have disconnected should be
  1083‚Üí#  buffered in-memory.
  1084‚Üí#  See also: MappingKernelManager.buffer_offline_messages
  1085‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.buffer_offline_messages = True
  1086‚Üí
  1087‚Üí## Whether to consider culling kernels which are busy.

  1089‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.cull_busy = False

  1091‚Üí## Whether to consider culling kernels which have one or more connections.

  1095‚Üí## Timeout (in seconds) after which a kernel is considered idle and ready to be

  1098‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.cull_idle_timeout = 0
  1099‚Üí
  1100‚Üí## The interval (in seconds) on which to check for idle kernels exceeding the

  1103‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.cull_interval = 300
  1104‚Üí
  1105‚Üí## The name of the default kernel to start

  1108‚Üí
  1109‚Üí## Timeout for giving up on a kernel (in seconds).

  1115‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.kernel_manager_class = 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'
  1116‚Üí
  1117‚Üí#  See also: MappingKernelManager.root_dir

  1122‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelManager.shared_context = True
  1123‚Üí

  1128‚Üí#  See also: KernelSpecManager.ensure_native_kernel
  1129‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelSpecManager.ensure_native_kernel = True
  1130‚Üí
  1131‚Üí## The kernel spec class.  This is configurable to allow

  1133‚Üí# c.GatewayKernelSpecManager.kernel_spec_class = 'jupyter_client.kernelspec.KernelSpec'

  1139‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1140‚Üí# GatewayClient(SingletonConfigurable) configuration
  1141‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1142‚Üí## This class manages the configuration.  It's its own singleton class so that we
  1143‚Üí#  can share these values across all objects.  It also contains some helper methods
  1144‚Üí#   to build request arguments out of the various config options.
  1145‚Üí
  1146‚Üí## The authorization token used in the HTTP headers.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_AUTH_TOKEN
  1147‚Üí#  env var)
  1148‚Üí#  Default: None
  1149‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.auth_token = None
  1150‚Üí
  1151‚Üí## The filename of CA certificates or None to use defaults.
  1152‚Üí#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CA_CERTS env var)
  1153‚Üí#  Default: None
  1154‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.ca_certs = None
  1155‚Üí
  1156‚Üí## The filename for client SSL certificate, if any.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CLIENT_CERT
  1157‚Üí#  env var)
  1158‚Üí#  Default: None
  1159‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.client_cert = None
  1160‚Üí
  1161‚Üí## The filename for client SSL key, if any.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CLIENT_KEY env var)
  1162‚Üí#  Default: None
  1163‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.client_key = None
  1164‚Üí
  1165‚Üí## The time allowed for HTTP connection establishment with the Gateway server.
  1166‚Üí#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CONNECT_TIMEOUT env var)
  1167‚Üí#  Default: 40.0
  1168‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.connect_timeout = 40.0
  1169‚Üí
  1170‚Üí## A comma-separated list of environment variable names that will be included,
  1171‚Üí#  along with their values, in the kernel startup request.  The corresponding
  1172‚Üí#  `env_whitelist` configuration value must also be set on the Gateway server -
  1173‚Üí#  since that configuration value indicates which environmental values to make
  1174‚Üí#  available to the kernel. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_ENV_WHITELIST env var)
  1175‚Üí#  Default: ''
  1176‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.env_whitelist = ''
  1177‚Üí
  1178‚Üí## Additional HTTP headers to pass on the request.  This value will be converted
  1179‚Üí#  to a dict. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_HEADERS env var)
  1180‚Üí#  Default: '{}'
  1181‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.headers = '{}'
  1182‚Üí
  1183‚Üí## The password for HTTP authentication.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_HTTP_PWD env var)
  1184‚Üí#  Default: None
  1185‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.http_pwd = None
  1186‚Üí
  1187‚Üí## The username for HTTP authentication. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_HTTP_USER env var)
  1188‚Üí#  Default: None
  1189‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.http_user = None
  1190‚Üí
  1191‚Üí## The gateway API endpoint for accessing kernel resources
  1192‚Üí#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_KERNELS_ENDPOINT env var)
  1193‚Üí#  Default: '/api/kernels'
  1194‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.kernels_endpoint = '/api/kernels'
  1195‚Üí
  1196‚Üí## The gateway API endpoint for accessing kernelspecs
  1197‚Üí#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_KERNELSPECS_ENDPOINT env var)
  1198‚Üí#  Default: '/api/kernelspecs'
  1199‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.kernelspecs_endpoint = '/api/kernelspecs'
  1200‚Üí
  1201‚Üí## The gateway endpoint for accessing kernelspecs resources
  1202‚Üí#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_KERNELSPECS_RESOURCE_ENDPOINT env var)
  1203‚Üí#  Default: '/kernelspecs'
  1204‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.kernelspecs_resource_endpoint = '/kernelspecs'
  1205‚Üí
  1206‚Üí## The time allowed for HTTP request completion. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_REQUEST_TIMEOUT
  1207‚Üí#  env var)
  1208‚Üí#  Default: 40.0
  1209‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.request_timeout = 40.0
  1210‚Üí
  1211‚Üí## The url of the Kernel or Enterprise Gateway server where kernel specifications
  1212‚Üí#  are defined and kernel management takes place. If defined, this Notebook
  1213‚Üí#  server acts as a proxy for all kernel management and kernel specification
  1214‚Üí#  retrieval.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_URL env var)
  1215‚Üí#  Default: None
  1216‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.url = None
  1217‚Üí
  1218‚Üí## For HTTPS requests, determines if server's certificate should be validated or
  1219‚Üí#  not. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_VALIDATE_CERT env var)
  1220‚Üí#  Default: True
  1221‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.validate_cert = True
  1222‚Üí
  1223‚Üí## The websocket url of the Kernel or Enterprise Gateway server.  If not
  1224‚Üí#  provided, this value will correspond to the value of the Gateway url with 'ws'
  1225‚Üí#  in place of 'http'.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_WS_URL env var)
  1226‚Üí#  Default: None
  1227‚Üí# c.GatewayClient.ws_url = None
  1228‚Üí
  1229‚Üí#------------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Allow password to be changed at login for the notebook server.

#  to the user to enter a new password at the same time that will replace the
#  token login mechanism.

## Allow requests where the Host header doesn't point to a local server
#  
#  By default, requests get a 403 forbidden response if the 'Host' header shows
#  that the browser thinks it's on a non-local domain. Setting this option to
#  True disables this check.

#  This protects against 'DNS rebinding' attacks, where a remote web server
#  serves you a page and then changes its DNS to send later requests to a local
#  IP, bypassing same-origin checks.

#  with hostnames configured in local_hostnames.

c.NotebookApp.allow_remote_access = True

# c.NotebookApp.terminado_settings = {}

## Set to False to disable terminals.
#  
#  This does *not* make the notebook server more secure by itself. Anything the
#  user can in a terminal, they can also do in a notebook.
#  
#  Terminals may also be automatically disabled if the terminado package is not
#  available.
#  Default: True
# c.NotebookApp.terminals_enabled = True

## Token used for authenticating first-time connections to the server.
#  
#  The token can be read from the file referenced by JUPYTER_TOKEN_FILE or set
#  directly with the JUPYTER_TOKEN environment variable.
#  
#  When no password is enabled, the default is to generate a new, random token.
#  
#  Setting to an empty string disables authentication altogether, which is NOT
#  RECOMMENDED.
#  Default: '<generated>'
# c.NotebookApp.token = '<generated>'

## X-Scheme/X-Forwarded-Proto „Åä„Çà„Å≥ X-Real-Ip/X-Forwarded-For
#  „Éò„ÉÉ„ÉÄ„Éº„Åå„Ç¢„ÉÉ„Éó„Çπ„Éà„É™„Éº„É†„ÅÆ„É™„Éê„Éº„Çπ„Éó„É≠„Ç≠„Ç∑„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶ÈÄÅ‰ø°„Åï„Çå„Åü„Åì„Å®„Çí‰ø°È†º„Åô„Çã„Åã„Å©„ÅÜ„Åã„ÄÇ„Éó„É≠„Ç≠„Ç∑„Åå SSL „ÇíÂá¶ÁêÜ„Åô„ÇãÂ†¥Âêà„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å®„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ
#  Default: False
# c.NotebookApp.trust_xheaders = False

## Disable launching browser by redirect file
#  
#  For versions of notebook > 5.7.2, a security feature measure was added that
#  prevented the authentication token used to launch the browser from being
#  visible. This feature makes it difficult for other users on a multi-user
#  system from running code in your Jupyter session as you.
#  
#  However, some environments (like Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) and
#  Chromebooks), launching a browser using a redirect file can lead the browser

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# ConnectionFileMixin(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Mixin for configurable classes that work with connection files

## JSON file in which to store connection info [default: kernel-<pid>.json]

#  This file will contain the IP, ports, and authentication key needed to connect

#  dir of the current profile, but can be specified by absolute path.
#  Default: ''
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.connection_file = ''

## set the control (ROUTER) port [default: random]
#  Default: 0
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.control_port = 0

## set the heartbeat port [default: random]
#  Default: 0
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.hb_port = 0

## set the iopub (PUB) port [default: random]
#  Default: 0
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.iopub_port = 0

## Set the kernel's IP address [default localhost]. If the IP address is
#  something other than localhost, then Consoles on other machines will be able
#  to connect to the Kernel, so be careful!
#  Default: ''
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.ip = ''

## set the shell (ROUTER) port [default: random]
#  Default: 0
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.shell_port = 0

## set the stdin (ROUTER) port [default: random]
#  Default: 0
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.stdin_port = 0

#  Choices: any of ['tcp', 'ipc'] (case-insensitive)
#  Default: 'tcp'
# c.ConnectionFileMixin.transport = 'tcp'

## JSON file in which to store connection info [default: kernel-<pid>.json]

# c.KernelManager.connection_file = ''

## set the control (ROUTER) port [default: random]

## set the heartbeat port [default: random]
#  See also: ConnectionFileMixin.hb_port
# c.KernelManager.hb_port = 0

## set the iopub (PUB) port [default: random]
#  See also: ConnectionFileMixin.iopub_port
# c.KernelManager.iopub_port = 0

## Set the kernel's IP address [default localhost].
#  See also: ConnectionFileMixin.ip
# c.KernelManager.ip = ''

## DEPRECATED: Use kernel_name instead.
#  
#  The Popen Command to launch the kernel. Override this if you have a custom
#  kernel. If kernel_cmd is specified in a configuration file, Jupyter does not
#  pass any arguments to the kernel, because it cannot make any assumptions about
#  the arguments that the kernel understands. In particular, this means that the
#  kernel does not receive the option --debug if it given on the Jupyter command
#  line.
#  Default: []
# c.KernelManager.kernel_cmd = []

## set the shell (ROUTER) port [default: random]

## Time to wait for a kernel to terminate before killing it, in seconds.

# c.KernelManager.shutdown_wait_time = 5.0

## set the stdin (ROUTER) port [default: random]

# c.KernelManager.stdin_port = 0

#  See also: ConnectionFileMixin.transport
# c.KernelManager.transport = 'tcp'

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Session(Configurable) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Object for handling serialization and sending of messages.
#  
#  The Session object handles building messages and sending them with ZMQ sockets
#  or ZMQStream objects.  Objects can communicate with each other over the
#  network via Session objects, and only need to work with the dict-based IPython
#  message spec. The Session will handle serialization/deserialization, security,
#  and metadata.
#  
#  Sessions support configurable serialization via packer/unpacker traits, and
#  signing with HMAC digests via the key/keyfile traits.
#  
#  Parameters ----------
#  
#  debug : bool
#      whether to trigger extra debugging statements
#  packer/unpacker : str : 'json', 'pickle' or import_string
#      importstrings for methods to serialize message parts.  If just
#      'json' or 'pickle', predefined JSON and pickle packers will be used.
#      Otherwise, the entire importstring must be used.
#  
#      The functions must accept at least valid JSON input, and output *bytes*.
#  
#      For example, to use msgpack:
#      packer = 'msgpack.packb', unpacker='msgpack.unpackb'
#  pack/unpack : callables
#      You can also set the pack/unpack callables for serialization directly.
#  session : bytes
#      the ID of this Session object.  The default is to generate a new UUID.
#  username : unicode
#      username added to message headers.  The default is to ask the OS.
#  key : bytes
#      The key used to initialize an HMAC signature.  If unset, messages
#      will not be signed or checked.
#  keyfile : filepath
#      The file containing a key.  If this is set, `key` will be initialized
#      to the contents of the file.

## Threshold (in bytes) beyond which an object's buffer should be extracted to
#  avoid pickling.
#  Default: 1024
# c.Session.buffer_threshold = 1024

## Whether to check PID to protect against calls after fork.
#  
#  This check can be disabled if fork-safety is handled elsewhere.
#  Default: True
# c.Session.check_pid = True

## Threshold (in bytes) beyond which a buffer should be sent without copying.
#  Default: 65536
# c.Session.copy_threshold = 65536

## Debug output in the Session
#  Default: False
# c.Session.debug = False

## The maximum number of digests to remember.
#  
#  The digest history will be culled when it exceeds this value.
#  Default: 65536
# c.Session.digest_history_size = 65536

## The maximum number of items for a container to be introspected for custom
#  serialization. Containers larger than this are pickled outright.
#  Default: 64
# c.Session.item_threshold = 64

## execution key, for signing messages.
#  Default: b''
# c.Session.key = b''

## path to file containing execution key.
#  Default: ''
# c.Session.keyfile = ''

## Metadata dictionary, which serves as the default top-level metadata dict for
#  each message.
#  Default: {}
# c.Session.metadata = {}

## The name of the packer for serializing messages. Should be one of 'json',
#  'pickle', or an import name for a custom callable serializer.
#  Default: 'json'
# c.Session.packer = 'json'

## The UUID identifying this session.
#  Default: ''
# c.Session.session = ''

## The digest scheme used to construct the message signatures. Must have the form
#  'hmac-HASH'.
#  Default: 'hmac-sha256'
# c.Session.signature_scheme = 'hmac-sha256'

## The name of the unpacker for unserializing messages. Only used with custom
#  functions for `packer`.
#  Default: 'json'
# c.Session.unpacker = 'json'

## Username for the Session. Default is your system username.
#  Default: 'wonder'
# c.Session.username = 'wonder'

## A class for managing multiple kernels.

## The name of the default kernel to start
#  Default: 'python3'
# c.MultiKernelManager.default_kernel_name = 'python3'

## The kernel manager class.  This is configurable to allow subclassing of the
#  KernelManager for customized behavior.
#  Default: 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'
# c.MultiKernelManager.kernel_manager_class = 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'

## Share a single zmq.Context to talk to all my kernels
#  Default: True
# c.MultiKernelManager.shared_context = True

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# MappingKernelManager(MultiKernelManager) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## A KernelManager that handles notebook mapping and HTTP error handling

## White list of allowed kernel message types. When the list is empty, all
#  message types are allowed.
#  Default: []
# c.MappingKernelManager.allowed_message_types = []

## Whether messages from kernels whose frontends have disconnected should be
#  buffered in-memory. When True (default), messages are buffered and replayed on
#  reconnect, avoiding lost messages due to interrupted connectivity. Disable if
#  long-running kernels will produce too much output while no frontends are
#  connected.
#  Default: True
# c.MappingKernelManager.buffer_offline_messages = True

## Whether to consider culling kernels which are busy. Only effective if
#  cull_idle_timeout > 0.
#  Default: False
# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_busy = False

## Whether to consider culling kernels which have one or more connections. Only
#  effective if cull_idle_timeout > 0.
#  Default: False
# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_connected = False

## Timeout (in seconds) after which a kernel is considered idle and ready to be
#  culled. Values of 0 or lower disable culling. Very short timeouts may result
#  in kernels being culled for users with poor network connections.
#  Default: 0
# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_idle_timeout = 0

## The interval (in seconds) on which to check for idle kernels exceeding the
#  cull timeout value.
#  Default: 300
# c.MappingKernelManager.cull_interval = 300

## The name of the default kernel to start
#  See also: MultiKernelManager.default_kernel_name
# c.MappingKernelManager.default_kernel_name = 'python3'

## Timeout for giving up on a kernel (in seconds). On starting and restarting
#  kernels, we check whether the kernel is running and responsive by sending
#  kernel_info_requests. This sets the timeout in seconds for how long the kernel
#  can take before being presumed dead. This affects the MappingKernelManager
#  (which handles kernel restarts) and the ZMQChannelsHandler (which handles the
#  startup).
#  Default: 60
# c.MappingKernelManager.kernel_info_timeout = 60

## The kernel manager class.  This is configurable to allow
#  See also: MultiKernelManager.kernel_manager_class
# c.MappingKernelManager.kernel_manager_class = 'jupyter_client.ioloop.IOLoopKernelManager'

#  Default: ''
# c.MappingKernelManager.root_dir = ''

## Share a single zmq.Context to talk to all my kernels
#  See also: MultiKernelManager.shared_context
# c.MappingKernelManager.shared_context = True

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# ContentsManager(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Base class for serving files and directories.
#  
#  This serves any text or binary file, as well as directories, with special
#  handling for JSON notebook documents.
#  
#  Most APIs take a path argument, which is always an API-style unicode path, and
#  always refers to a directory.
#  
#  - unicode, not url-escaped
#  - '/'-separated
#  - leading and trailing '/' will be stripped
#  - if unspecified, path defaults to '',
#    indicating the root path.

## Allow access to hidden files
#  Default: False
# c.ContentsManager.allow_hidden = False

#  Default: None
# c.ContentsManager.checkpoints = None

#  Default: 'notebook.services.contents.checkpoints.Checkpoints'
# c.ContentsManager.checkpoints_class = 'notebook.services.contents.checkpoints.Checkpoints'

#  Default: {}
# c.ContentsManager.checkpoints_kwargs = {}

## handler class to use when serving raw file requests.
#  
#  Default is a fallback that talks to the ContentsManager API, which may be
#  inefficient, especially for large files.
#  
#  Local files-based ContentsManagers can use a StaticFileHandler subclass, which
#  will be much more efficient.
#  
#  Access to these files should be Authenticated.
#  Default: 'notebook.files.handlers.FilesHandler'
# c.ContentsManager.files_handler_class = 'notebook.files.handlers.FilesHandler'

## Extra parameters to pass to files_handler_class.
#  
#  For example, StaticFileHandlers generally expect a `path` argument specifying
#  the root directory from which to serve files.
#  Default: {}
# c.ContentsManager.files_handler_params = {}

## Glob patterns to hide in file and directory listings.
#  Default: ['__pycache__', '*.pyc', '*.pyo', '.DS_Store', '*.so', '*.dylib', '*~']
# c.ContentsManager.hide_globs = ['__pycache__', '*.pyc', '*.pyo', '.DS_Store', '*.so', '*.dylib', '*~']

## Python callable or importstring thereof
#  
#  To be called on a contents model prior to save.
#  
#  This can be used to process the structure, such as removing notebook outputs
#  or other side effects that should not be saved.
#  
#  It will be called as (all arguments passed by keyword)::
#  
#      hook(path=path, model=model, contents_manager=self)
#  
#  - model: the model to be saved. Includes file contents.
#    Modifying this dict will affect the file that is stored.
#  - path: the API path of the save destination
#  - contents_manager: this ContentsManager instance
#  Default: None
# c.ContentsManager.pre_save_hook = None

#  Default: '/'
# c.ContentsManager.root_dir = '/'

## The base name used when creating untitled directories.
#  Default: 'Untitled Folder'
# c.ContentsManager.untitled_directory = 'Untitled Folder'

## The base name used when creating untitled files.
#  Default: 'untitled'
# c.ContentsManager.untitled_file = 'untitled'

## The base name used when creating untitled notebooks.
#  Default: 'Untitled'
# c.ContentsManager.untitled_notebook = 'Untitled'

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# FileManagerMixin(Configurable) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Mixin for ContentsAPI classes that interact with the filesystem.
#  
#  Provides facilities for reading, writing, and copying both notebooks and
#  generic files.
#  
#  Shared by FileContentsManager and FileCheckpoints.
#  
#  Note ---- Classes using this mixin must provide the following attributes:
#  
#  root_dir : unicode
#      A directory against against which API-style paths are to be resolved.
#  
#  log : logging.Logger

## By default notebooks are saved on disk on a temporary file and then if
#  successfully written, it replaces the old ones. This procedure, namely
#  'atomic_writing', causes some bugs on file system without operation order
#  enforcement (like some networked fs). If set to False, the new notebook is
#  written directly on the old one which could fail (eg: full filesystem or quota
#  )
#  Default: True
# c.FileManagerMixin.use_atomic_writing = True

# FileContentsManager(FileManagerMixin, ContentsManager) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#  See also: ContentsManager.checkpoints_kwargs
# c.FileContentsManager.checkpoints_kwargs = {}

## If True (default), deleting files will send them to the platform's

## handler class to use when serving raw file requests.

## Extra parameters to pass to files_handler_class.

## 
#  See also: ContentsManager.hide_globs
# c.FileContentsManager.hide_globs = ['__pycache__', '*.pyc', '*.pyo', '.DS_Store', '*.so', '*.dylib', '*~']

## Python callable or importstring thereof
#  
#  to be called on the path of a file just saved.
#  
#  This can be used to process the file on disk, such as converting the notebook
#  to a script or HTML via nbconvert.
#  
#  It will be called as (all arguments passed by keyword)::
#  
#      hook(os_path=os_path, model=model, contents_manager=instance)
#  
#  - path: the filesystem path to the file just written - model: the model
#  representing the file - contents_manager: this ContentsManager instance

## Python callable or importstring thereof

## DEPRECATED, use post_save_hook. Will be removed in Notebook 5.0

## The base name used when creating untitled directories.

## The base name used when creating untitled files.
#  See also: ContentsManager.untitled_file
# c.FileContentsManager.untitled_file = 'untitled'

## The base name used when creating untitled notebooks.
#  See also: ContentsManager.untitled_notebook
# c.FileContentsManager.untitled_notebook = 'Untitled'

## By default notebooks are saved on disk on a temporary file and then if
#  successfully written, it replaces the old ones.
#  See also: FileManagerMixin.use_atomic_writing
# c.FileContentsManager.use_atomic_writing = True

## The kernel spec class.  This is configurable to allow

# c.GatewayKernelSpecManager.kernel_spec_class = 'jupyter_client.kernelspec.KernelSpec'

## Whitelist of allowed kernel names.
#  See also: KernelSpecManager.whitelist
# c.GatewayKernelSpecManager.whitelist = set()

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# GatewayClient(SingletonConfigurable) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## This class manages the configuration.  It's its own singleton class so that we
#  can share these values across all objects.  It also contains some helper methods
#   to build request arguments out of the various config options.

## The authorization token used in the HTTP headers.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_AUTH_TOKEN
#  env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.auth_token = None

## The filename of CA certificates or None to use defaults.
#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CA_CERTS env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.ca_certs = None

## The filename for client SSL certificate, if any.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CLIENT_CERT
#  env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.client_cert = None

## The filename for client SSL key, if any.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CLIENT_KEY env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.client_key = None

## The time allowed for HTTP connection establishment with the Gateway server.
#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_CONNECT_TIMEOUT env var)
#  Default: 40.0
# c.GatewayClient.connect_timeout = 40.0

## A comma-separated list of environment variable names that will be included,
#  along with their values, in the kernel startup request.  The corresponding
#  `env_whitelist` configuration value must also be set on the Gateway server -
#  since that configuration value indicates which environmental values to make
#  available to the kernel. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_ENV_WHITELIST env var)
#  Default: ''
# c.GatewayClient.env_whitelist = ''

## Additional HTTP headers to pass on the request.  This value will be converted
#  to a dict. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_HEADERS env var)
#  Default: '{}'
# c.GatewayClient.headers = '{}'

## The password for HTTP authentication.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_HTTP_PWD env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.http_pwd = None

## The username for HTTP authentication. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_HTTP_USER env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.http_user = None

## The gateway API endpoint for accessing kernel resources
#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_KERNELS_ENDPOINT env var)
#  Default: '/api/kernels'
# c.GatewayClient.kernels_endpoint = '/api/kernels'

## The gateway API endpoint for accessing kernelspecs
#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_KERNELSPECS_ENDPOINT env var)
#  Default: '/api/kernelspecs'
# c.GatewayClient.kernelspecs_endpoint = '/api/kernelspecs'

## The gateway endpoint for accessing kernelspecs resources
#  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_KERNELSPECS_RESOURCE_ENDPOINT env var)
#  Default: '/kernelspecs'
# c.GatewayClient.kernelspecs_resource_endpoint = '/kernelspecs'

## The time allowed for HTTP request completion. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_REQUEST_TIMEOUT
#  env var)
#  Default: 40.0
# c.GatewayClient.request_timeout = 40.0

## The url of the Kernel or Enterprise Gateway server where kernel specifications
#  are defined and kernel management takes place. If defined, this Notebook
#  server acts as a proxy for all kernel management and kernel specification
#  retrieval.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_URL env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.url = None

## For HTTPS requests, determines if server's certificate should be validated or
#  not. (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_VALIDATE_CERT env var)
#  Default: True
# c.GatewayClient.validate_cert = True

## The websocket url of the Kernel or Enterprise Gateway server.  If not
#  provided, this value will correspond to the value of the Gateway url with 'ws'
#  in place of 'http'.  (JUPYTER_GATEWAY_WS_URL env var)
#  Default: None
# c.GatewayClient.ws_url = None

#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# TerminalManager(LoggingConfigurable) configuration
#------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## 

## Timeout (in seconds) in which a terminal has been inactive and ready to be
#  culled. Values of 0 or lower disable culling.
#  Default: 0
# c.TerminalManager.cull_inactive_timeout = 0

## The interval (in seconds) on which to check for terminals exceeding the
#  inactive timeout value.
#  Default: 300
# c.TerminalManager.cull_interval = 300
